title: Before 2 October 2021, will the UN General Assembly recognize delegates from the National Unity Government (NUG) as representing Myanmar for the 76th General Assembly session?
preds:
Triggered by a comment by @MCowley below, on "optimism" and "specific recognition from the UNGA", and just hours before the question closes (with the crowd still at 0%), let me wrap-up and summarize for one last time the evidence that I think shows that the question has already been resolved as a "Yes". (There's nothing new here, only stuff that I have already posted in the last ~ 5-10 days) As per the latest reports from credible sources, Kyaw Moe Tun remains the Myanmar representative to the UNGA for the time being, and at least until the Credentials Committee meets in November:
https://www.reuters.com/world/myanmar-will-not-address-world-leaders-un-afghanistan-will-2021-09-24/ (Sep 24)
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/27/world/unga-afghanistan-taliban-isaczai-intl/index.html (Sep 27)
https://apnews.com/article/united-nations-general-assembly-asia-afghanistan-voting-myanmar-33b3c02fe1d72b30a6890e73bab42fbd ("It is a rare feather in the diplomatic cap of the shadow government", Sep 27)
https://www.irrawaddy.com/in-person/interview/international-pressure-essential-in-war-against-junta-myanmars-un-ambassador.html (Sep 30) following a plan first reported by Foreign Policy and later confirmed by the Wall Street Journal:
https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/09/13/myanmar-united-nations-china-biden-general-assembly/
https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-and-china-avert-potential-clash-in-u-n-over-myanmar-representation-11632234248 On Sep 24, The Conversation (supposedly famous for their FactCheck unit, https://theconversation.com/the-conversations-factcheck-granted-accreditation-by-international-fact-checking-network-at-poynter-74363) reported that Kyaw Moe Tun was able to participate in the opening session of the 76th UNGA, claiming that "this was a big win for the NUG":
https://theconversation.com/two-governments-claim-to-run-myanmar-so-who-gets-the-countrys-seat-at-the-un-167885 The fact that Kyaw Moe Tun chose not to speak at the UNGA high-level general debate is irrelevant to the question, and, according to the reports above, it was voluntary and not due to any formal objection by any state or UN body; UNGA president spoke on record on Sep 28, explicitly confirming and clarifying this:
https://www.wionews.com/world/myanmar-did-not-make-a-request-to-speak-unga-president-abdulla-shahid-clarifies-to-wion-416617 In any case, and according to the question clarification of Sep 13, provisional recognition counts. Notice here that the UNGA is by no means confined to the high-level general debate of September, and it goes on until at least August 2022:
https://www.un.org/en/ga/76/meetings/ Notice the quoted statement by the UN Secretary-General spokesman in CNN (https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/27/world/unga-afghanistan-taliban-isaczai-intl/index.html) regarding the fact that the Afghan representative, too, chose not to speak in the general debate: "This does not change the fact that the representative of Afghanistan remains the same". The cases of Afghanistan & Myanmar here are formally equivalent: both representatives had their credentials challenged, both remain in their position until the Credentials Committee meets and reports, and both removed themselves from the general debate speaker list voluntarily. As of Sep 23, according to the State Department and the US Embassy in Burma (sic), Kyaw Moe Tun was still the Burmese (sic) UN Permanent Representative:
https://www.state.gov/counselor-chollets-meeting-with-burmese-representatives/
https://twitter.com/usembassyburma/status/1441184315052679168 Last but not least, as of today, Kyaw Moe Tun is still listed as the Myanmar Permanent Representative in the official page of the UN Protocol and Liaison Service:
https://bluebook.unmeetings.org/ (choose "Member States maintaining permanent missions in Headquarters" in the 1st pull-down menu and "Myanmar" in the 2nd) The fact that Kyaw Moe Tun does represent the NUG is arguably clear and unambiguous:
https://mizzima.com/article/ambassador-u-kyaw-moe-tun-speaks-mizzima ("So, I am representing the NUG" in interview)
https://www.myanmarmissionnewyork.org/links together with https://www.myanmarmissionnewyork.org/permanent-representative And with that, I rest my case. Let's see...

While I like some people's optimism, the question seems to require specific recognition from the UNGA and as it states "attendance alone would not count", as noted in their example of 2 rival delegations from Venezuela both sitting in session.  I'm rounded up to 1%.

Here is Kyaw Moe Tun in an interview published today, Sep 30, by The Irrawaddy (which refers to him as "Myanmar UN ambassador" in the title): https://www.irrawaddy.com/in-person/interview/international-pressure-essential-in-war-against-junta-myanmars-un-ambassador.html  He summarizes the (mostly known, by now) situation nicely and clearly; excerpts: -------------------
Though the military council dismissed me, the UN and member states recognize me as the permanent representative. [..]  So it was decided by consensus to keep me. [...] The credentials committee, I understand, has had informal meetings with member countries about my case.  As ASEAN, the European Union, US and UK reached an agreement, other countries have also agreed to keep me in my position. [...] The credentials committee will have a formal meeting in November and review the issue and report to the General Assembly.  The General Assembly is not a week-long meeting. It started on September 14 and continues until September 2022. [...] Our delegation will be able to speak at the plenary sessions and standing committees. We agreed [not to address the general debate] to best serve our country in the long term. [...] We have opportunities to address those meetings about the situation in Myanmar. We believe we will convey the voices of Myanmar’s people through those channels.   My understanding is that there will be a meeting in November [to discuss Myanmar’s representation]. The credentials committee has used the word “continuity”, so I understand I will remain in my position for the 76th session.
------------------- Also, the UNGA president spoke on record on Sep 28, clarifying explicitly that Kyaw Moe Tun's removal from the UNGA general debate speaker list was voluntary, and not due to any formal objection by any state or UN body whatsoever:
https://www.wionews.com/world/myanmar-did-not-make-a-request-to-speak-unga-president-abdulla-shahid-clarifies-to-wion-416617 As of today, Kyaw Moe Tun is still listed as the Myanmar Permanent Representative in the official page of the UN Protocol and Liaison Service:
https://bluebook.unmeetings.org/ (choose "Member States maintaining permanent missions in Headquarters" in the 1st pull-down menu and "Myanmar" in the 2nd) The fact that Kyaw Moe Tun does represent the NUG is arguably clear and unambiguous:
https://mizzima.com/article/ambassador-u-kyaw-moe-tun-speaks-mizzima ("So, I am representing the NUG" in interview)
https://www.myanmarmissionnewyork.org/links together with https://www.myanmarmissionnewyork.org/permanent-representative

Most probably, and for the time frame of the question, this has been resolved by now, as laid out in my previous rationale https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1335986 . Reuters (Sep 25) https://www.reuters.com/world/myanmar-will-not-address-world-leaders-un-afghanistan-will-2021-09-24/ :
----------------
diplomats said China, Russia and the United States had reached an understanding, where Moscow and Beijing will not object to Kyaw Moe Tun remaining in Myanmar's U.N. seat for the moment as long as he does not speak during the high-level meeting. Until a decision is made by the credentials committee on both Afghanistan and Myanmar, Isaczai and Kyaw Moe Tun will remain in the seats, according to the General Assembly rules.
----------------- AP today (Sep 27) https://apnews.com/article/united-nations-general-assembly-asia-afghanistan-voting-myanmar-33b3c02fe1d72b30a6890e73bab42fbd :
-----------------
The current envoy, Ambassador Kyaw Moe Tun [...] For at least a couple of months, he appears likely to keep his seat — or at least deny it to an appointee of the military government. It is a rare feather in the diplomatic cap of the shadow government, which has not been recognized by any nation
----------------- CNN today (Sep 27) https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/27/world/unga-afghanistan-taliban-isaczai-intl/index.html :
-----------------
Kyaw Moe Tun was also scheduled to speak Monday, but confirmed to CNN that he had withdrawn. He declined to comment on the reason, but cited a Foreign Policy report describing a US-China-brokered deal to hold off on granting UN credentials to the junta. There is an understanding between Russia, China and the United States regarding Myanmar not speaking as long as Ambassador Kyaw Moe Tun remains in his post, a UN diplomat has separately told CNN. "I withdrew from the speaker list in order to keep the seat for the people of Myanmar," Kyaw Moe Tun said.
---------------- The Conversation (https://theconversation.com/two-governments-claim-to-run-myanmar-so-who-gets-the-countrys-seat-at-the-un-167885) confirms that the incumbent representative was able to participate in the opening of the general assembly session on Sep 14 (https://twitter.com/DrSasa22222/status/1438433948607004673?s=20), commenting that "this was a big win for the NUG". Speaking about the similar case of Afghanistan (in the sense that both existing representatives with challenged credentials did not address the UNGA general debate), UN Secretary-General spokesman Stéphane Dujarric said "This does not change the fact that the representative of Afghanistan remains the same", which is naturally applicable for Myanmar as well:  https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/27/world/unga-afghanistan-taliban-isaczai-intl/index.html Since he is not attending the General Debate, which ends today, no point of order is expected. And the credentials committee is not expected to meet before November or late October.

The United Nations General Assembly will consider the credentials of all representatives of all member States, but an issue can be raised as to whether the representative is accredited by Government actually in power. This is pertinent in this case.
Membership in the Organisation, in accordance with its charter is open to all peace-loving States and that they are able to carry out such obligations.
The NUG has announced a ‘peoples defensive war against the junta and so abandoning the non-violent tactics of Suu Kyi as adopted during her house arrest. This is perceived as an overt call to violence with a potential outbreak of civil war, which can hardly be countenanced by the UN and its charter.
Member States are not minded in recognising an authority ‘in exile’ as the legitimate government, given the difficulty in defining ‘legitimate’. https://theconversation.com/two-governments-claim-to-run-myanmar-so-who-gets-the-countrys-seat-at-the-un-167885  https://www.un.org/en/about-us/about-un-membership  https://www.ilsa.org/Jessup/Jessup12/Talmon_Who%20is%20a%20legitimate%20government%20in%20exile.pdf

In an exclusive interview in Myanmar magazine Mizzima (https://mizzima.com/article/ambassador-u-kyaw-moe-tun-speaks-mizzima), Kyaw Moe Tun confirms the plan first reported in Foreign Policy and later in the Wall Street Journal (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1335986); some relevant excerpts: --------------------
Although the Credentials Committee has been formed on 14 September. The Committee normally holds its meeting in November. It considered holding the meeting immediately this year. However, it will be convened in November and will discuss the credentials there. So, I will retain my seat. As the Credentials Committee has not decided on the proposed credentials of the junta regime, I will have to continue the incumbent position. Therefore, I delivered a speech on some occasions during the 76th session of UNGA. The report of Foreign Policy magazine is consistent with our knowledge on this issue to a certain degree. I was instructed to make a speech at the meetings of high-level General Debate between 21 and 27 September. The instruction was also seen on the 27 September schedule. But I also withdrew the instruction after comprehensive discussions at other platforms for ensuring a long-term continuity as the scheduled speech on 27 September is not essential. So, the arrangement was made the exclusion of Myanmar ‘s Permanent Representative at the General Debate. But I could make speeches at the meetings of 6 main committees from 27 September to December which is the main period for UNGA. Most of the countries expect me as a Permanent Representative of the elected government, and that they always refer me for this position. I here express the concern of the Myanmar people, which is also the voice of NUG. So, I am representing the NUG.

WSJ yesterday [1] updated on the plan first revealed by FP last week [2, 3]: -------------------------------------
U.S. and China Avert Potential Clash in U.N. Over Myanmar Representation Myanmar’s permanent representative to the United Nations [...] will sit out a series of high-level meetings in New York this week. [...] The compromise allows Kyaw Moe Tun to participate in all U.N. functions after the annual “general debate” ends next week [...] “This seat will not be taken by a representative of the military, that is for sure,” Mr. Kyaw Moe Tun said in an interview, adding that he won’t make a speech or be present for the event. “In the long run, there will be a lot of occasions for me to deliver many, many statements—there will be a plenary, there will be committees—that’s very important to me and to the country.” The nine-member [credentials] committee [...] will meet in November to weigh a decision. Mr. Kyaw Moe Tun said he doesn’t anticipate a challenge meanwhile, and expects continuity until and after the meeting.
------------------------------------ So, as I see it, if this scenario plays out as planned, when the question closes on Oct 2, Kyaw Moe Tun will still be the permanent representative of Myanmar in the GA, even provisionally, representing the NUG. An important detail (and point of possible confusion) is that the 76th Session of the UN General Assembly, which the question is explicitly about, goes on until September 2022, and it does *not* end with the end of the general debate next week. If I had any doubts previously as to Kyaw Moe Tun being considered as an NUG representative, they went away after checking the weekly formal letters he has been sending to the UN Secretary-General [4], where it is explicit that he recognizes and represents NUG as the legitimate government of Myanmar (well, even the people portrayed in the front page of [4] are NUG officials, and the Links section consists exclusively of links to NUG and its ministries). Still, there are many things ambiguous and unclear (including the interpretation of the outcome by GJO), that keep me clear from the high confidence zone (80-100). --------------------------------------

BREAKING (Sep 13) from Foreign Policy: U.S. and China Reach Deal to Block Myanmar’s Junta From U.N.:
https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/09/13/myanmar-united-nations-china-biden-general-assembly/
https://twitter.com/KevinCChang/status/1437721732069085185 Excerpts:
--------------
The United States and China have brokered an agreement that will effectively block Myanmar’s military rulers from addressing the United Nations’ General Assembly next week, according to diplomats But the pact—which was hammered out during weeks of behind-the-scenes diplomatic negotiations—will require Myanmar’s defiant, still-serving U.N. ambassador who represented the previous government to hold his tongue during the high-level event, refraining from the tough rhetoric he deployed last year in denouncing the military’s power grab. The arrangement, which was described by multiple diplomatic sources and representatives of advocacy groups familiar with internal deliberations, has been informally endorsed by representatives of the European Union, members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and Russia.  The United States and its European allies were concerned that a country sympathetic to the military regime’s claims might appeal to the credential committees to take up the matter before its first scheduled meeting in November. They are hoping to delay any decision on Myanmar’s representation as long as possible, preserving a diplomatic stalemate that ensures Myanmar’s current ambassador, Kyaw Moe Tun, will maintain his right to Myanmar’s U.N. seat. “We’re interested in keeping the status quo as long as we can,” said one diplomat from a country involved in the discussions.  In a brief telephone interview, Kyaw Moe Tun confirmed that international negotiations are underway to determine how to move forward on Myanmar’s U.N. seat. He said he would “most likely not” deliver an address to the U.N. General Assembly, even though the list of speakers for the assembly includes Myanmar The deal involved an arrangement in which U.N. member states would agree to put off any discussion in the U.N. Credentials Committee of the military junta’s diplomatic status until after the U.N.’s annual diplomatic jamboree. In the meantime, Kyaw Moe Tun [...] has agreed not to address the assembly during the session or sit in Myanmar’s seat in the General Assembly. In the telephone interview, Kyaw Moe Tun did not confirm whether Myanmar’s seat will remain empty during the high-level debate.  Discussion on the fate of Myanmar’s diplomatic representation will be put off until at least November, when the U.N. Credentials Committee will convene to consider a request by Myanmar’s military regime to install its chosen envoy to represent Myanmar at the world body.  “What we are hearing, and this seems to be increasingly solid, is that the credential committee will defer. They will say they can’t draw a firm conclusion now, and that will encourage [Kyaw Moe Tun] to stay on,” said Richard Gowan, the U.N. representative at the International Crisis Group. But Kyaw Moe Tun will not represent the country’s National Unity Government “Apparently, there has been a quiet gentleman’s agreement that the current ambassador will keep a low profile during [this] high-level week and won’t use it as an opportunity to attack the regime,” Gowan added. Some in Washington see the effort to keep the junta away from the U.N. gathering as a key step to denying it further international legitimacy. “It would be useful to ensure that the Tatmadaw [military] does not have representatives at the U.N., as you know, because I think that gives them automatic credibility,” said one congressional committee aide, speaking on condition of anonymity. “It’s something we don’t want to see.”
----------------- Now, I am not sure how we should read this "Kyaw Moe Tun will not represent the country’s National Unity Government". I can take it to mean simply that Kyaw Moe Tun will not *speak* as NUG representative during the UNGA General Debate (i.e. keeping a low profile, in accordance with other excerpts above and the apparent spirit of the alleged deal); an alternative reading could be that he will explicitly agree not to be considered as representing NUG, but this does not seem to be supported by the rest of the article. And if he does not represent NUG, who exactly will he be representing? Thoughts? In the meantime, and until further updates emerge, I am throttling down from 79% to 66% solely due to this uncertainty.

"Until a decision is made on Myanmar's accreditation, Suu Kyi's Ambassador Kyaw Moe Tun will remain in the seat, according to the General Assembly rules." "While the junta requested that its foreign minister Wunna Maung Lwin lead a delegation to the high-level U.N. gathering it will likely be Kyaw Moe Tun who addresses the world body on Sept. 27, diplomats said."

Why the UN should recognise Myanmar’s National Unity Government, not the junta (Sep 13, https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/opinion/article/3148326/why-un-should-recognise-myanmars-national-unity-government-not , essentially a wrap up of this legal opinion: https://the-world-is-watching.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Myanmar-Legal-Opinion-Final-2.pdf); by Richard J. Goldstone, founding Chief Prosecutor of the UN International Criminal Tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda, co-signed by 10 legal scholars: "We, the undersigned legal scholars, recommend that the junta’s credentials be rejected." "There is a sound legal case for the General Assembly to take this course of action, based on historical precedents." "In the last three decades, the General Assembly has consistently refused to accept the credentials of regimes that have come to power by overthrowing democratically elected governments, in violation of national constitutions, as the military junta has in Myanmar" [Haiti 1993, Sierra Leone 1997, Honduras 2009, Libya 2011] "The General Assembly has increasingly been willing to approve the credentials of governments and groups even where they lacked effective control of the entire territory of the state." "Neither the NUG nor the junta is in effective control of all Myanmar, though the NUG, supported by ethnic nationalities’ parties, is in effective control of more territory than the regime." "We believe there are compelling legal arguments to accept the credentials of the NUG." --- That said, we have to keep in mind that legal arguments are maybe necessary but certainly not sufficient, and that the final decision of the UNGA will be political in nature. It just doesn't hurt to know that the option of recognizing the credentials of NUG is backed by solid legal and historical arguments.

The recent (Sep 8) Legal Opinon: the Representation of the State of the Union of Myanmar at the United Nations [1] seems to re-iterate the 4 possible scenarios as laid out in the Briefing Paper: Myanmar’s representation in the United Nations [2], unearthed by @GMR, which I have already analyzed (always IMO) previously [3]. Quoting: ---------------------------
"50. There are broadly four options that the UN Credentials Committee must decide upon. 51. First, the Credentials Committee could recommend acceptance of the credentials of the
military junta. [...] Based on these considerations the Credentials Committee should not recommend to 
the UN General Assembly that the credentials issued by the Myanmar military junta be accepted. 52. Second, the Credentials Committee could recommend acceptance of the credentials of the
NUG. [...] Based on these considerations the Credentials Committee should recommend to the
UN General Assembly that the credentials of the representatives of the NUG be
accepted. The Credentials Committee has made similar decisions in relation to Liberia
(1990-97), Sierra Leone (1996), Haiti (1991-94), and Honduras (2009). 53. Third, the Credentials Committee could defer a decision on the credentials. [...]
on the understanding that Myanmar’s current Permanent
Representative to the UN in New York, Kyaw Moe Tun, continue to represent Myanmar
provisionally at the General Assembly. [...] The Credentials Committee should
only defer the decision if it can provide well founded reasons why it has not been able
to accept the credentials of the NUG. The Credentials Committee has made similar
decisions in relation to Afghanistan (1997-2001), Guinea (2009-10) and Madagascar
(2009) and Guinea-Bissau (2012). 54. Fourth, the Credentials Committee could decide to leave the seat of Myanmar vacant at the
UN General Assembly. It could do this either by deferring its decision on credentials,
explicitly on the understanding that no one will represent Myanmar at the Assembly’s 76th
session (as in the case of Cambodia in 1997), or by deciding not to accept any credentials
submitted for Myanmar (as in the case of South Africa during the apartheid regime, albeit
in that case without any competing credentials). [...] The Credentials Committee should not
recommend that the seat of Myanmar be left vacant at the UN General Assembly."
------------------------------ As already noticed before [2, 3], under a "regular" process, the Credentials Committee is not expected to issue a report before the question closes on Oct 2; nevertheless, the scenarios described above will be applicable in the case that some State raises the issue of Myanmar representation as a "point of order", and the Credentials Committee will indeed be required to report before Oct 2. And here is NYT, reporting today (Sep 11) about the representation of Myanmar and Afghanistan in the forthcoming UNGA [4]: "“I think the Credentials Committee will indulge in what we might call creative procrastination,” said Richard Gowan, the U.N. director at the International Crisis Group. Such a delay, he said, would allow both ambassadors “to stay in the post for the time being, albeit on fragile ground.”" 
As stated previously, I *assume* that a deferral allowing (pro-NUG) Kyaw Moe Tun to continue to represent Myanmar provisionally at the GA would resolve the question in the positive, but I am not certain about that, hence my forecast is not higher towards a "yes". ----------------

Renshaw, C. (2021, Aug, 10). The battle for Myanmar’s seat in the UN General Assembly. Lowy Institute. The Interpreter. Retrieved from 
https://www.lowyinstitute.org/the-interpreter/battle-myanmar-s-seat-un-general-assembly An empty chair in New York would be a potent reflection of the situation on the ground in post-coup Myanmar. Across Myanmar, the battle continues between the military and those opposed to the military coup d’etat of 1 February 2021. Opposition to the coup began with non-violent resistance in the form of the Civil Disobedience Movement. The aim is now revolution and an end to the military’s decades-long dominance of political life. The revolutionaries have brought within their fold some of the armed ethnic organisations that have long fought against the military in the country’s borderlands. Civil war is looming. A different battle for Myanmar is being fought in the United Nations. On 14 September, the 75th UN General Assembly (UNGA) will meet in New York. Presidents, prime ministers and dictators from across the world – or their representatives – will gather to discuss, debate and make recommendations on global issues. The question de jour is who will represent Myanmar – the military’s representative or the representative of the democratically elected, ousted government? It is the job of a nine-country Credentials Committee to make a recommendation to the UNGA about whose credentials to accept. It is rare for the Committee to accept the credentials of an ousted government that does not hold power or control territory, but it is not unprecedented (Haiti in 1992, Sierra Leone in 1997). In some contentious cases, the Committee has deferred making any decision at all (Afghanistan in 1996 and Cambodia in 1997).

1 - Formalities The whole issue will be dealt with in a very specific context, i.e. that of the UN system. What's more, any decision by the UN General Assembly (GA) to reject the credentials of the military government in favor of NUG will not pose any kind of restrictions whatsoever regarding bilateral diplomatic relations of UN member states with Myanmar; this is clearly stated in the GA Resolution 396(V), "Recognition by the United Nations of the representation of a Member State" [1]: "[The GA] Declares that the attitude adopted by the General Assembly or its Interim Committe concerning any such question shall not of itself affect the direct relations of individual Member States with the State concerned;" Bottom line here: "Dear Myanmar military, we can reject you from representing Myanmar in the GA, and still be friends (i.e. maintain normal diplomatic relations)". Arguably, this leaves much flexibility on the table for states that will choose to do so; such states can still send a (strong) message without formally breaking relationships with the military regime. --- 2 - History Similar rejections of (military) governments from the GA in favor of democratically elected and/or exiled ones have happened many times in the past: "In the cases of Cambodia, Sierra Leone, Afghanistan, Liberia and Haiti, 
the Credentials Committee either deferred a decision on the credentials
of the government or accredited a former representative instead of the
government effectively in control of the territory" [2] Useful to remind here that the decisions of both the Credentials Committee and the GA itself are taken by simple majority, and there is no kind of veto involved (so Russia and China cannot block such a decision on their own). --- 3 - Situation on the ground There have been multiple attempts by Myanmar since February to remove and replace their current UN Permanent Representative, Kyaw Moe Tun, but all of them have been steadily rejected so far by the UN system [3][4][5]. At the time of writing, Kyaw Moe Tun is still listed as UN ambassador of Myanmar in the UN Protocol and Liaison Service [6]. According to AP [4], his Feb 26 dramatic speech to a GA meeting against the military takeover drew loud applause from diplomats in the assembly chamber who called it “powerful,” “brave” and “courageous” (reminder that this is the same GA that will be asked to choose who will represent Myanmar in its next annual session). --- 4 - US stance These rejections by the UN system mentioned above are actively backed and supported by the current US ambassador to the UN, Linda Thomas-Greenfield [3]. Thomas-Greenfield wrote an opinion piece in the Washington Post [7] back on March 2021, praising current Myanmar ambassador Kyaw Moe Tun, listing what measures the US have already taken against the military regime in Myanmar, and culminating with a statement: "We will do more. And we need our allies and regional partners to do more, too." [7] Which, to me, sounds like a call to arms for US partners and allies. Thomas-Greenfield has steadily since backed her OP with public tweets [8][9], assuring that the US will escalate and sustain pressure toward the Myanmar military regime. Far from being any kind of "rogue" diplomat with a possible personal agenda, Thomas-Greenfield was just recently chosen to lead the US Presidential Delegation to the closing ceremony of the Tokyo Olympics [10]; most likely, her words and actions have the explicit approval of her superiors in the US State Department (if not of the White House). And to make the situation even worse for the Myanmar military regime, an alleged plot to assassinate current Myanmar ambassador to the UN Kyaw Moe Tun was just recently uncovered by the FBI [11][12][13]. Attempting such an assassination on US soil sounds like adding insult to injury; as we could easily guess, Ambassador Thomas-Greenfield was not at all happy, and she made that explicit [14][15]. --- 5 - Other considerations A recent (July 2021) UK parliamentary report, titled "The UK Government’s Response to the Myanmar Crisis" [16], seems to be all in favor of recognizing NUG as the legitimate government of Myanmar; quoting from Section 2 [17]: --
8 [in bold]. If the UK is to fulfil its unique potential to mediate, it has to demonstrate a willingness to take action beyond statements. A coherent and concerted response is needed by the United Nations if the junta is to feel any real pressure. Actions should be taken to de-legitimise the junta’s authority, block its supply of arms, and encourage regional actors to take firmer measures. The National Unity Government (NUG) 9. The National Unity Government of Myanmar consists of parliamentarians elected in the 2020 election, members of various ethnic groups, and figures in the anti-coup movement.12 Given the evidence we have heard, and the NUG’s active role in promoting democracy in Myanmar, we believe that they, not the junta, represent the legitimate and expressed will of the Myanmar people.13 However, the UK Government’s policy of recognising states, rather than governments, is an obstacle to the recognition of these legitimate representatives. 10 [in bold]. The UK Government cannot be said to support democracy in Myanmar if it does not recognise the outcome of democratic elections in Myanmar. The National Unity Government comprises the legitimate representatives of the people of Myanmar, whose election has been found valid by third party observers. Rather than an exile government, the NUG should be treated as a government-in-waiting.
-- Even if "the UK Government’s policy of recognising states, rather than governments, is an obstacle to the recognition of these legitimate representatives", as stated in para 8 above, this does not prohibit actions related to the UN GA representation (which the question here is about), in the spirit of what I have already pointed out in section 1 above. --- CONCLUSION & ASSESSMENT Given the situation as described above, I think the crowd's assessment here (currently at 0%) grossly underestimates the actual odds. ---------------
